Steelers Daily News & Links: Terry Bradshaw Deserves More From Historians; Mike Tomlin on Impact of 7-on-7
Steelers Daily News & Links: Your daily stop for all of the news and links from the Pittsburgh Steelers, NFL and around the Sports Now Group
? Former Pittsburgh Post-Gazette writer Vito Stellino, who covered the Pittsburgh Steelers in the 1970s, thinks quarterback Terry Bradshaw deserves more from historians.
‚ÄúIn the 1970s and 1980s, there were two quarterbacks who dominated the NFL, and each led a Team of the Decade ‚Äì Terry Bradshaw in the 1970s and Joe Montana in the 1980s. Bradshaw won four Super Bowls in six years and repeated twice; Montana won four Super Bowls in nine years and repeated once. From 1974-89, they won eight of the 16 Super Bowls. ‚Ä¶ So you might think they‚Äôre ranked similarly in the pantheon of great quarterbacks. Surprisingly, they aren‚Äôt,‚Äù Stellino wrote on The Talk of Fame as a guest columnist.
‚ÄúMontana is considered one of the best quarterbacks in NFL history, generally ranked second to Tom Brady. In fact, when the Talk of the Fame Two conducted a recent poll of historians, Brady, Montana, John Unitas and Otto Graham were named to the Mt. Rushmore of quarterbacks.
‚ÄúI could live with that foursome if Bradshaw was considered No. 5. But historian John Turney recently put together a list of the Top Ten and didn‚Äôt include him, and I found another ranking on the internet where Bradshaw was only ranked 17th. I admit that I may not be the most objective observer since I covered his four Super Bowl years for the Pittsburgh Post-Gazette, but I am stunned at how underrated Bradshaw is.
‚ÄúTo start with, he made long game-winning throws in the fourth quarters of two of his Super Bowl wins. Furthermore, he beat Hall-of-Famer Roger Staubach twice in Super Bowls ‚Ä¶ with a Team of the Decade on the line in the second ‚Ä¶ and twice was named a Super Bowl MVP.‚Äù
Many have expressed recently that Terry Bradshaw deserves to have his No. 12 jersey officially retired with the Steelers. Given his career accolades, it‚Äôs hard to disagree that he deserves more recognition.
